Introduction
I am an evolutionary ecologist studying the ecology, physiology, and evolutionary history of life in aquatic environments. I am particularly interested in adaptations of life to 'extreme' ambient conditions, such as prevailing in polar and deep seas, as well as in macroecology patterns of reproduction and development. I develop scientific theory of global significance. My work assists the protection and conservation of the oceans. E-mail contact: sthatje@icloud.com ORCID: 0000-0001-8727-0115

Questions

Question (1)
Should Research Councils pay their reviewers for the assessment of research grant proposals?
Question
  • Apr 2021
Research Councils both national and international distribute large amounts of research funding among scientists, and this process is the essence that makes scientific work possible. Submitted research grant proposals are usually assessed for quality by >2 peers. Only few research councils do already pay (usually modest fees) for peer review. Given that in many other areas of academia e.g. some social sciences, engineering, medicine, quality assessment reports (unrelated to grant assessment) are generally being paid for, should research councils pay for peer review and across any field of science? And if so, what do you think how high such fees should be? How should these be calculated? What does speak against paying peers for their efforts? Research project assessment is time consuming and depending an experts' views to guarantee the quality of proposed research and to justify research funding expenses to the public-at-large. Would paying reviewers some (reasonable) fees make a difference in the overall expense?
View
  • 2 Answers
